abstracts.cdata!:
The Tanzania Emergency Power Supply
            Project, which finances emergency measures to reduce power
            supply interruptions, discusses potential environmental
            impacts and proposes measures to mitigate them. High
            priority recommendations include: arranging the safe
            disposal of old transformers and scrap material, educating
            workers about the safe handling of hazardous substances,
            supplying firefighting equipment, preventing soil and water
            contamination by building a containment slab and oil-stained
            waste storage area, preparing and testing and emergency
            plan, regularly checking water quality for underground
            contamination, repairing oil separator equipment and
            building a second interceptor for power house effluents,
            improving awareness of proper storage and disposal of oil
            and fuel waste, educating workers about health risks of
            PCBs, removing and replacing contaminated soil, repairing
            air conditioners, equipping first aid kits with essential
            drugs, and replenishing lost or broken lids or slabs to
            avoid risks of injury or death. Medium-level concerns
            include:  conducting regular environmental performance
            reviews, reducing noise impacts by repairing and maintaining
            machines and enforcing protective gear, conducting regular
            acoustic surveys, posting signs of high noise levels,
            providing worker training programs in health and safety
            issues, installing electronic monitoring devices to check
            quality of discharged effluents, in storage areas
            providing/posting additional labeling, warning, and
            instruction--preferably in a local language-for safety and
            proper handling of hazardous substances, and setting up a
            decontamination area.
